statement.p: A ball is dropped from a state of rest at time t=0.
The distance traveled after t seconds is s(t)=16t^2 ft.
(a) How far does the ball travel during the time interval [2,{2.5}] ?
{\Delta}s= ft
(b) Compute the average velocity over [2,{2.5}] .
(c) Compute the average velocity over time intervals [2, 2.01] , [2, 2.001] , [2, 2.0001] , [1.9999, 2] , [1.999, 2] , [1.99, 2] .
Use this to estimate the object's instantaneous velocity at t={2} .

static.solution:
Solution:
(a) Galileo's formula is s(t)=16t^2. The ball thus travels
\Delta s=s(2.5)-s(2)=16 \cdot 2.5^2 - 16 \cdot 2^2 = 36 \enspace ft.
(b) The average velocity over [2, 2.5] is
\frac {\Delta s} {\Delta t} = \frac {s(2.5)-s(2)} {2.5 - 2} = \frac {16 \cdot 2.5^2 - 16 \cdot 2^2} {2.5 - 2} =\frac {36}{0.5} = 72 \enspace ft/s.
(c)
time interval average velocity

[2, 2.001] 64.0159999999952
[2, 2.0001] 64.0016000001253
[1.9999, 2] 63.9984000000027
[1.999, 2] 63.9839999999907
[1.99, 2] 63.8399999999997
The instantaneous velocity at t=2 is 64 ft/s.

Given that \small{f(4) = -9} and \small{f'(4) = -6}, find an equation for the tangent line to the graph of \small{y = f(x)} at \small{x = 4}.

static.solution:
\small{f'(4) = -6}, the slope of the tangent line at \small{x = 4} is \small{-6}. Since \small{f(4) = -9}, the tangent line contains the point \small{(4,-9)}.
Therefore, the equation of the tangent line to \small{f(x)} at \small{x = 4} is \small{y + 9 = -6(x - 4)}, or \small{y = -6 x + 15}.

Given that f(3) = -4 and f'(3) = -1, approximate f(3.2).

static.solution:
Solution:
Using the formula, f(c + h) \approx f(c) + f'(c)\cdot h, f(3.2) = f(3 + 0.2) \approx f(3) + f'(3)\cdot (0.2) = -4 - 1 \cdot (0.2) = -4.2.

statement.p: Given that P(111) = 21 and P'(111) = 9, approximate P(114).

static.solution:
Solution:
Using the formula, f(c + h) \approx f(c) + f'(c)\cdot h, with the function P, P(114) = P(111 + 3) \approx P(111) + P'(111)\cdot (3) = 21 + 9 \cdot (3) = 48.

solution.p: SOLUTION
The derivative of f(x) = 4 \sin x is f'(x) = 4 \cos x.

So the slope of the tangent line at \left(\frac{ \pi}{6} , 2\right) is m = f'\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 4 \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 4 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = 2 \sqrt{3} Therefore the equation of the tangent line is y - 2 = 2 \sqrt{3} \left( x -\frac{ \pi}{6}\right) \quad \text{or} \quad y = \sqrt{3} x + 2 - 2 \sqrt{3} \frac{\pi}{6} Thus b = 2 - {\frac{1}{3}} \sqrt{3} \pi

statement.p: Find the equation of the tangent line to the curve y=x+7 \cos{x} at the point (0,7).
Compute the derivative of the given function in two different ways.
a) Use the Product Rule, [fg]' = f\cdot g' + f' \cdot g. (Fill in each blank, then simplify.)
b) Use algebra first to simplify h, then differentiate without the Product Rule.

static.solution:
Solution:
First, using the Product Rule,
\begin{array}{rcl} h'(s) \amp =\amp (7 s + 5) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}[ 8 s - 3 ] + \frac{d}{dx}[ 7 s + 5 ] (8 s - 3)\\ \amp \amp \\ \amp =\amp (7 s + 5)(8) + (7)(8 s - 3) \\ \end{array} After simplifying the last line, we find h'(s) = 112 s + 19.
Next, simplify h first. Then take the derivative. \begin{array}{rcl} h(s) \amp =\amp (7 s + 5)(8 s - 3) = 56 s^2 + 19 s - 15 \\ \amp \amp \\ h'(s) \amp =\amp 112 s + 19 \end{array} The two simplified answers should match.

Calculate the derivative using the appropriate rule or combination of rules. f(x)=\frac{e^{x}}{\left(e^{x}+5\right)\mathopen{}\left(x+5\right)}

static.solution: f'(x) we begin with quotient rule f'(x)= \frac{(e^x+5)(x+5)\frac{d}{dx}[e^x]-e^x\frac{d}{dx}[(e^x+5)(x+5)]}{((e^x+5)(x+5))^2}. Next, recall that \frac{d}{dx}[e^x]=e^x, and use the product rule to compute \frac{d}{dx}[(e^x+5)(x+5)]=\frac{d}{dx}[e^x+5](x+5)+(e^x+5)\frac{d}{dx}[x+5] which is (e^x)(x+5)+(e^x+5)(1). Therefore f'(x)= \frac{(e^x+5)(x+5)\cdot e^x-e^x\cdot (e^x(x+5)+(e^x+5))}{((e^x+5)(x+5))^2} and after factoring out e^x in the numerator, expanding (e^x+5)(x+5)=xe^x+5\cdot e^x+5 x+5\cdot 5, and distributing the minus sign, we get f'(x)=\frac{e^x(xe^x+5 x+5 e^x - xe^x-5 e^x-e^x-5)}{((e^x+5)(x+5))^2} which simplifies to f'(x)=\frac{e^x(5 x - e^x-5)}{((e^x+5)(x+5))^2}.

Use the figure below to estimate the indicated derivatives, or state that they do not exist. If a derivative does not exist, enter dne in the answer blank. The graph of f(x) is black and has a sharp corner at x = 2. The graph of g(x) is blue.
Let h(x) = f(x)\cdot g(x). Find

p.em: (Enter dne for any derivative that does not exist.)

solution.p: Using the product rule, we know that h'(x) = f'(x) \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot g'(x). We use slope to compute the derivatives. Since f(x) is linear on the interval 0 \lt x \lt 2, we compute the slope of the line to see that f'(x) = 2 on this interval. Similarly, we compute the slope on the interval 2 \lt x \lt 4 to see that f'(x) = -2 there. Since f(x) has a corner at x = 2, we know that f'(2) does not exist. Similarly, g(x) is linear on the interval shown, and we see that the slope of g(x) on this interval is -0.75, so we have g'(x) = -0.75 on this interval.
B. We would like to say h'(2) = f'(2) \cdot g(2) + f(2) \cdot g'(2), but actually can't apply the product rule here, because f(x) has a corner at x = 2, and is therefore not differentiable there.

However, for these functions f(x) and g(x) the product rule does apply for all points to the left and right of x=2, and because the two functions are piecewise linear we can see that for x\lt 2, h'(x) = 3 and for x>2, h'(x) = -3. Thus h(x) has the same characteristic non-differentiability as f(x) at x=2, and we can say that h'(2) does not exist.

Let j(x) = \dfrac {g(x)}{f(x)}. Find

solution.p: SOLUTION

Using the quotient rule, we know that j'(x) = (g'(x) \cdot f(x) - g(x) \cdot f'(x))/(f(x))^2. We use slope to compute the derivatives. Since f(x) is linear on the interval 0 \lt x \lt 2, we compute the slope of the line to see that f'(x) = 2 on this interval. Similarly, we compute the slope on the interval 2 \lt x \lt 4 to see that f'(x) = -2 on that interval. Since f(x) has a corner at x = 2, we know that f'(2) does not exist. Similarly, g(x) is linear on the interval shown, and we see that the slope of g(x) on this interval is -0.5 so we have g'(x) = -0.5 on this interval.

B. We have j'(2) = (g'(2) \cdot f(2) - g(2) \cdot f'(2))/(f(2)^2). Since f(x) has a corner at x = 2 we know that f'(2) does not exist. This results in the derivative of the quotient j(x) not existing at this point, as suggested by the quotient rule given here, and thus j'(2) does not exist.

Let f(x) = \sqrt{ 7 - 2 x } .

Which of the following decompositions of f(x) = p (q(x) ) into a pair of functions p(x) (the outside function) and q(x) (the inside function) is/are correct ? Select all that apply if more than one is appropriate.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
There is often many (even infinite) ways to decompose a given function into a suitable pair of inside and outside functions. In this case, the following decompositions work: \begin{aligned} p(x) = \sqrt{x},\amp \qquad q(x) = 7 - 2 x \\ p(x) = \sqrt{7 - x}\amp \qquad q(x) = 2 x \\ p(x) = \sqrt{-x} \amp \qquad q(x) = 2 x - 7 \end{aligned}
The other choices do not work since:
If p(x) = 7 - 2 x and q(x) = \sqrt{x}, then p(q(x)) = 7 - 2 \sqrt{x} \ne f(x).
if p(x) = \sqrt{7 + x} and q(x) = 2 x, then p(q(x)) = \sqrt{7+2 x} \ne f(x).
if p(x) = \sqrt{- 2 x} and \ q(x) = 7 + x, then p(q(x)) = \sqrt{-2 x - 14} \ne f(x).

statement.p: Consider the graphs below, which give m(x) in the left graph, in black, and n(x) in the right graph, in blue. Both functions have a sharp corner at x = 50.
Let h(x) = n(m(x)). Find a point x where h'(x) = -0.14.

solution.p: Since the chain rule gives h'(x) = n'(m(x)) m'(x) = -0.14 we must find values a and x such that a=m(x) and n'(a) m'(x)= -0.14.

Calculating slopes from the graph of n gives n'(a) = 1.4 for 0 \lt a \lt 50 and n'(a) = 0.1 for 50 \lt a \lt 100. Similarly calculating slopes from the graph of m gives m'(x) = -1.4 for 0 \lt x \lt 50 and m'(x) = 1.4 for 50 \lt x \lt 100.

The only values of the derivative n' are 1.4 and 0.1 and the only values of the derivative m' are -1.4 and 1.4. In order to have n'(a) m'(x)= -0.14 we must therefore have n'(a)=0.1 and m'(x) = -1.4. Thus 50 \lt a \lt 100 and 0 \lt x \lt 50.

Now a=m(x) and from the graph of m we see that 50 \lt m(x) \lt 100 for 0 \lt x \lt 35.71 or 64.29 \lt x \lt 100. The two conditions on x we have found are both satisfied when 0 \lt x \lt 35.71. Thus h'(x)= -0.14 for all x in the interval 0 \lt x \lt 35.71. The question asks for just one of these x values (any will work).

Let f(x) = \sin( \arccos( x) ).
a) First find the derivative by using Chain Rule.

b) Next, we will find the derivative in a different way. Rewrite f(x) without trigonometric functions (Hint: Set up a right triangle with a side x). When you have finished this step, f(x) can be written as:
Then find the derivative of this equivalent form of f.

static.solution:
Solution:
\dfrac{d}{dx}\left[ \sin(\arccos( x)) \right] = \cos(\arccos( x)) \cdot \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} = \frac{-x}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}. Let \theta = \arccos( x). Then \cos \theta = \frac{x}{1}. Now in a triangle with leg x and hypotenuse 1, the remaining side is equal to \sqrt{1 - x^2}. This implies that \sin \theta = \frac{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}{1} = \sqrt{1 - x^2}. But \sin \theta is exactly \sin(\arccos( x)) = f(x). Next, find the derivative: \dfrac{d}{dx}\left[ \sqrt{1 - x^2} \right] = \dfrac{1}{2}(1 - x^2)^{-1/2}(-2x) = \dfrac{-x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}. The answer should match the derivative you found in the first part.

Find the slope of the tangent line to the curve defined by 6x^{2}+7xy+9y^{5} = 42 at the point ( -3,1 ).
The slope of the curve at the point (-3, 1) is .

solution.p: Differentiating implicitly with respect to x gives 12x+7y+7x\, \frac{dy}{dx}+45y^{4}\, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, or \left(7x+45y^{4}\right)\, \frac{dy}{dx} = -(12x+7y), and so \frac{dy}{dx} = -\frac{12x+7y}{7x+45y^{4}}. Hence, the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the given point is \frac{dy}{dx} \bigg \vert _ {(x, y) = (-3, 1)} = -\frac{12\cdot \left(-3\right)+7\cdot 1}{7\cdot \left(-3\right)+45\cdot 1^{4}} \textstyle =\frac{29}{24} .

statement.p: Find the equation of the tangent line to the curve x^4 + y^4 = 32 at the point (2, -2).
Tangent line equation: y =

static.solution:
Solution:
First use implicit differentiation to find the derivative. \begin{array}{rcl} \dfrac{d}{dx}[x^4 + y^4] \amp =\amp \dfrac{d}{dx}[32]\\ \amp \amp \\ 4x^3 + 4y^3y' \amp =\amp 0\\ \amp \amp \\ y' \amp =\amp \dfrac{-4x^3}{4y^3} = -\dfrac{x^3}{y^3} \end{array} Plug in (x = 2\) (y = -2\) get the slope. m = -\dfrac{(2)^3}{(-2)^3} = -1 Then use point-slope form to find the equation of the tangent line. y + 2 = -1(x - 2) \; \textrm{or,} \; y = -1 x + 0

statement.p: Find the slope of the tangent line to the curve \sqrt{4x+y}+\sqrt{3xy} = 10 at the point (3, 4).
The slope of the tangent line to the curve at the given point is .

solution.p: Differentiating implicitly with respect to x gives \frac{4}{2 \sqrt{4x+y}} + \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{4x+y}} \, \frac{dy}{dx} + \frac{3}{2 \sqrt{3xy}} \left( y + x \, \frac{dy}{dx} \right) = 0, or (multiplying by 2 \sqrt{3xy} \sqrt{4x+y}) 4 \sqrt{3xy} + 1 \sqrt{3xy} \; \frac{dy}{dx} + 3 y \sqrt{4x+y} + 3 x \sqrt{4x+y} \; \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, so \left( 1 \sqrt{3xy} + 3 x \sqrt{4x+y} \right) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = - \left( 4 \sqrt{3xy} + 3 y \sqrt{4x+y} \right), and therefore \frac{dy}{dx} = - \frac {4 \sqrt{3xy} + 3 y \sqrt{4x+y}}{1 \sqrt{3xy} + 3 x \sqrt{4x+y}}. If x = 3 and y = 4, then \sqrt{4x+y} = 4, \sqrt{3xy} = 6, and hence the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the point (3, 4) is \frac{dy}{dx} \Bigg|_{(x, y) = (3, 4)} = - \frac {4 \left( 6 \right) + 3 \left( 4 \right) \left( 4 \right)} {1 \left( 6 \right) + 3 \left( 3 \right) \left( 4 \right)} = -{\frac{12}{7}}.

statement.p: If x^{5} + y^3 - 2 x y^2 = 33, find dy/dx in terms of x and y.
Using your answer for dy/dx, fill in the following table of approximate y-values of points on the curve near x=1, y=4.
Finally, find the y-value for x=0.96 by substituting x=0.96 in the original equation and solving for y using a computer or calculator.
How large (in magnitude) is the difference between your estimate for y(0.96) using dy/dx and your solution with a computer or calculator?

static.solution:
5 x^{4} + 3 y^2 \frac{dy}{dx} - 2 y^2 - 4 x y \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, so that {dy\over dx} = \frac{2 y^2 - 5 x^{4}}{3y^2 - 4 x y}.
We can approximate the curve near x=1, y=4 by its tangent line. The tangent line will have slope \frac{2 (4)^2 - 5 (1)^{4}}{3 (4)^2 - 4 (1) (4)} \approx 0.844. Thus its equation is y \approx 4 + 0.844(x - 1).
Using the y-values of the tangent line to approximate the y-values of the curve, we get y(0.96) \approx 3.9663, y(0.98) \approx 3.9831, y(1.02) \approx 4.0169, and y(1.04) \approx 4.0338.
When x=0.96, we get the equation (0.96)^{5} + y^3 - 2 (0.96) y^2 = 33, whose solution by numerical methods (for example, using a calculator) is 3.96609.
The difference between 3.96609 and the estimate is just |3.96609 - 3.9663| = 0.0002.

statement.p: If 38 + 3f(x) + x^2 \left( f(x) \right)^3 = 0 and f(2) = -2, find f'(2).
The curve with equation 2y^3+y^2-y^5=x^4-2x^3+x^2 has been likened to a bouncing wagon (graph it to see why).
Find the x-coordinates of the points on this curve that have horizontal tangents. List them below, separating the values with commas.
Use implicit differentiation to find the points where the parabola defined by x^{2}-2xy+y^{2}+4x-8y+16 = 0 has horizontal and vertical tangent lines.
The parabola has horizontal tangent lines at the .
The parabola has vertical tangent lines at the point(s) .

solution.p: Differentiating implicitly with respect to x gives 2x-2y-2x\, \frac{dy}{dx}+2y\, \frac{dy}{dx}+4-8\, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, or (y-x-4) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = y-x-2, and so \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y-x-2}{y-x-4}. The tangent line to the parabola is horizontal where \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, i.e., where x - y = -2. The equation of the parabola can be written in the form \left(x-y\right)^{2}+4\mathopen{}\left(x-y\right)+16-4y = 0, and x - y = -2 gives 12 = 4y, or y = 3, and x = 1. Hence, the tangent line to the parabola is horizontal at the point \left(1,3\right) and nowhere else.

The tangent line the the parabola is vertical where 0 = \frac{dx}{dy} = \frac{y-x-4}{y-x-2}, i.e., where x - y = -4. Together with the last displayed equation of the parabola, this gives 16 - 4y = 0, or y = 4, and x = 0. Hence, the tangent line to the parabola is vertical at the point \left(0,4\right) and nowhere else.

statement.p: Find dy/dx in terms of x and y if \arcsin(x^{3} y) = x y^{3}.

static.solution: x. \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^{6} y^2}} (3 x^{2} y + x^{3} \frac{dy}{dx}) = y^{3} + 3 x y^{2} \frac{dy}{dx}, so, clearing the denominator, 3 x^{2} y + x^{3} \frac{dy}{dx} = \sqrt{1 - x^{6} y^2} (y^{3} + 3 x y^{2} \frac{dy}{dx}). Thus ( x^{3} - (3 x y^{2}) \sqrt{1 - x^{6} y^2} ) \frac{dy}{dx} = y^{3} \sqrt{1 - x^{6} y^2} - 3 x^{2} y, and finally \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y^{3} \sqrt{1 - x^{6} y^2} - 3 x^{2} y}{x^{3} - (3 x y^{2}) \sqrt{1 - x^{6} y^2}}.

statement.p: If x^2 + y^2 = 36 and dx/dt=3, find dy/dt when y is positive and

static.solution:
2x \frac{dx}{dt} + 2y\frac{dy}{dt} = 0 and hence \frac{dy}{dt} = -\frac{x\frac{dx}{dt}}{y}.
(a) When x=0, y=\sqrt{36-0^2}=6, so we have \frac{dy}{dt} = -\frac{0\cdot3}{6} = 0.
(b) When x=2, y=\sqrt{36-2^2}=\sqrt{32}, so we have \frac{dy}{dt} = -\frac{2\cdot3}{\sqrt{32}}.
(c) When x=4, y=\sqrt{36-4^2}=\sqrt{20}, so we have \frac{dy}{dt} = -\frac{4\cdot3}{\sqrt{20}}.

statement.p: Let \>l\> be the length of a diagonal of a rectangle whose sides have lengths \>x\> and \>y\>, and assume that \>x\> and \>y\> vary with time.

If \>x\> increases at a constant rate of \> \frac {1} {5}\> ft/s and \>y\> decreases at a constant rate of \> \frac {1} {6}\> ft/s, how fast is the size of the diagonal changing when \>x = 4\> ft. and \>y = 9\> ft?

A rectangle has one side of 9 cm. How fast is the area of the rectangle changing at the instant when the other side is 13 cm and increasing at 5 cm per minute? (Give units.)
Answer:

static.solution:
9 cm and that the other (say, the height) is increasing at 5 cm/min when it is 13 cm.
Differentiating the equation A = wh with respect to t and treating the width w as constant, we have \frac{dA}{dt} = w\frac{dh}{dt} = 9\cdot5 = 45 \hbox{ cm}^2\hbox{/min}.

A boat is pulled into a dock by means of a rope attached to a pulley on the dock. The rope is attached to the front of the boat, which is 6 feet below the level of the pulley.
If the rope is pulled through the pulley at a rate of 10 ft/min, at what rate will the boat be approaching the dock when 100 ft of rope is out?
The boat will be approaching the dock at ft/min.
Hint: Sketch a diagram of this situation.

A rope, attached to a weight, goes up through a pulley at the ceiling and back down to a worker. The worker holds the rope at the same height as the connection point between the rope and weight. The distance from the connection point to the ceiling is 30 ft. Suppose the worker stands directly next to the weight (i.e., a total rope length of 60 ft) and begins to walk away at a constant rate of 4 ft/s. How fast is the weight rising when the worker has walked:

static.solution:
Solution:
The worker, weight and pulley form a right triangle with height 30, base length x, and hypotenuse z. The speed at which the weight rises is the same as the speed the rope is being pulled. This means the rate we are looking for is \dfrac{dz}{dt}.
By the Pythagorean Theorem, x^2 + 30^2 = z^2 Take time-derivatives of both sides of the equation. 2x\dfrac{dx}{dt} = 2z\dfrac{dz}{dt}.
Then plug in \dfrac{dx}{dt} = 4 and solve for the unknown rate. \dfrac{dz}{dt} = \dfrac{4 x}{z}.
When x = 10, 10^2 + 30^2 = z^2 \;\Rightarrow\; z = \sqrt{1000}. \Rightarrow \dfrac{dz}{dt} = \dfrac{40}{\sqrt{1000}} \approx 1.26491106406735.
When x = 30, 30^2 + 30^2 = z^2 \;\Rightarrow\; z = \sqrt{1800}. \Rightarrow \dfrac{dz}{dt} = \dfrac{120}{\sqrt{1800}} \approx 2.82842712474619.

statement.p: A voltage V across a resistance R generates a current I=V/R. If a constant voltage of 12 volts is put across a resistance that is increasing at a rate of 0.4 ohms per second when the resistance is 3 ohms, at what rate is the current changing? (Give .)
rate =

static.solution: dR/dt=0.4 when R=3 and V=12 and we want to know dI/dt. Differentiating I=V/R with V constant gives \frac{dI}{dt}=V\left(-\frac{1}{R^2}\frac{dR}{dt}\right), so substituting gives \frac{dI}{dt}=12\left(-\frac{1}{3^2}\cdot 0.4\right) \approx -0.5333 \hbox{ amp/s }. (Note that we know the units are amp/s from the Leibnitz form of the derivative, dI\over dt. It is, of course, equally correct to use the expression on the right-hand side to determine the units, \left(\frac{\hbox{V}}{\hbox{ohm}{}^2}\right)\left(\frac{\hbox{ohm}}{\hbox{s}}\right), or, in homework-friendly form, V/ohm*s.)

How fast is the height of the pile increasing when the pile is 10 ft high?

If the trough is being filled with water at a rate of .2\,m^3/min, how fast is the water level rising when the water is 30\,cm deep?

How fast is cart B moving toward Q at the instant when cart A is 5\,ft from Q?

Also, the mechanism for focusing the camera has to take into account the increasing distance from the camera to the rising rocket. Let's assume the rocket rises vertically and its speed is 600\,ft/s when it has risen 3000\,ft.

(b) If the television camera is always kept aimed at the rocket, how fast is the camera's angle of elevation changing at that same moment?

(b) rad/s
